action.action-desc: Mr. Davidson introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committee on Rules, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To provide for congressional review of the imposition of duties and other trade measures by the executive branch, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Global Trade Accountability Act of 2023.

section.header: Congressional review of unilateral trade actions

subsection.text: Chapter 5 of title I of the Trade Act of 1974 (19 U.S.C. 2191 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Congressional review of unilateral trade actions

paragraph.text: In this section, the term unilateral trade action means any of the following actions taken with respect to the importation of an article pursuant to a provision of law specified in paragraph (2):

subparagraph.text: A prohibition on importation of the article.
The imposition of or an increase in a duty applicable to the article.
The imposition or tightening of a tariff-rate quota applicable to the article.
The imposition or tightening of a quantitative restriction on the importation of the article.
The suspension, withdrawal, or prevention of the application of trade agreement concessions with respect to the article.
Any other restriction on importation of the article.

paragraph.text: The provisions of law specified in this paragraph are the following:

subparagraph.text: Section 122.
Title III.
Sections 406, 421, and 422.
Section 338 of the Tariff Act of 1930 (19 U.S.C. 1338).
Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 (19 U.S.C. 1862).
Section 103(a) of the Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 (19 U.S.C. 4202(a)).
The Trading with the Enemy Act (50 U.S.C. 4301 et seq.).
The International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.).
Any provision of law enacted to implement a trade agreement to which the United States is a party.

paragraph.header: Exception for technical corrections to Harmonized Tariff Schedule
paragraph.text: A technical correction to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States shall not be considered a unilateral trade action for purposes of this section.

subsection.text: Except as provided by subsection (d), a unilateral trade action may not take effect unless—

paragraph.text: the President submits to Congress and to the Comptroller General of the United States a report that includes—

subparagraph.text: a description of the proposed unilateral trade action;
the proposed effective period for the action;
an analysis of the action, including whether the action is in the national economic interest of the United States;
an assessment of the potential effect of retaliation from trading partners affected by the action; and
a list of articles that will be affected by the action by subheading number of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States; and

paragraph.text: a joint resolution of approval is enacted pursuant to subsection (e).

subsection.text: Not later than 15 days after the submission of the report required by subsection (b)(1) with respect to a proposed unilateral trade action, the Comptroller General shall submit to Congress a report on the proposed action that includes an assessment of the compliance of the President with the provision of law specified in subsection (a)(2) pursuant to which the action would be taken.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, a unilateral trade action may take effect for one 90-calendar-day period (without renewal) if the President—

paragraph.text: determines that is necessary for the unilateral trade action to take effect because the action is—

subparagraph.text: necessary because of a national emergency;
necessary because of an imminent threat to health or safety;
necessary for the enforcement of criminal laws; or
necessary for national security; and

paragraph.text: submits written notice of the determination to Congress.

For purposes of this subsection, the term joint resolution means only a joint resolution of either House of Congress, the matter after the resolving clause of which is as follows: That Congress approves the action proposed by the President under section 155(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 in the report submitted to Congress under that section on _______., with the blank space being filled with the appropriate date.

After a House of Congress receives a report under subsection (b)(1) with respect to a unilateral trade action, the majority leader of that House (or his or her respective designee) shall introduce (by request, if appropriate) a joint resolution—

subparagraph.text: in the case of the House of Representatives, within 3 legislative days; and
in the case of the Senate, within 3 session days.

paragraph.text: The provisions of subsections (b) through (f) of section 152 shall apply to a joint resolution under this subsection to the same extent those provisions apply to a resolution under section 152.

subsection.header: Report by the United States International Trade Commission
subsection.text: Not later than 12 months after the date of a unilateral trade action taken pursuant to this section, the United States International Trade Commission shall submit to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives a report on the effects of the action on the United States economy, including a comprehensive assessment of the economic effects of the action on producers and consumers in the United States.
